headline.main-hed: Senate Panel Approves FERC Nominees, Keystone XL Bill

alt-summary-body.p: A Senate committee voted to confirm two of President Barack Obama's nominees to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and approved the Keystone XL pipeline in a meeting that displayed partisan differences over energy.

headline.main-hed: Senate panel approves FERC nominees, Keystone XL bill
Senate Panel Approves FERC Nominees, Keystone XL Bill
Senate Panel Approves FERC Nominees, Keystone XL Bill

summary-body.p: A Senate committee voted to confirm two of President Barack Obama's nominees to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and approved the Keystone XL pipeline in a meeting that displayed partisan differences over energy.

headline.main-hed: Senate Panel Approves FERC Nominees, Keystone XL Bill
headline.deck: Meeting Shows Partisan Differences Over Energy

article-body.byline: By Amy Harder and Michelle Hackman

media.media-caption: Sen. Lisa Murkowski speaks on the Keystone XL pipeline in February as Sen. Mary Landrieu, left, listens.

article-body.p: A Senate committee voted to confirm two nominees to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and separately approved the Keystone XL pipeline, as the panel's chairwoman, Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, sought to assert herself on energy issues that could help her in a tough race for re-election.
Neither vote came easily, showing the degree to which energy issues have become politically charged in an election year.
"It went much better than it could have gone," Ms. Landrieu said after the meeting. "They were very, very tough issues before the committee."

In passing the Keystone XL bill, Ms. Landrieu pushed the measure through with the support of Republicans and just one fellow Democrat, Joe Manchin of West Virginia. But the Republicans pressed Ms. Landrieu to use her influence with her party's leader, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada, to make sure the Keystone-approval bill made it to the Senate floor.

highlight.link: Premiums Rise at Big Insurers, Fall at Small Rivals Under Health Law

link.highlight: Poll Shows Erosion in President's Support

list-item.link: Sign Up: Receive the Capital Journal Daybreak newsletter in your inbox

article-body.p: The nominations to FERC also were difficult votes even though confirmations for the federal agency, which is tasked with regulating the nation's electric grid, traditionally haven't been contentious. Members of the committee were wrangling up to the vote over who would chair the commission.

The committee's consideration of the nominees was marked by disarray, with senators speaking out of order and Ms. Landrieu at one point nearly losing a quorum of senators necessary to vote. Ultimately the committee approved the nomination of Norman Bay by a vote of 13-9 and the nomination of Cheryl LaFleur 21-1.

Largely at the behest of Mr. Reid, President Barack Obama earlier this year nominated Mr. Bay to be FERC chairman and demoted Ms. LaFleur, who has been acting chairwoman since late last year, to commissioner.
Mr. Obama first nominated her to FERC in 2010. Several Republicans on Wednesday said they wanted Ms. LaFleur to remain as chairwoman, questioning whether Mr. Bay was ready to take the helm.

Just minutes before the vote on Mr. Bay, Ms. Landrieu said the White House and Mr. Reid had agreed that Ms. LaFleur would be chairwoman for another nine months once the full Senate votes to confirm her and Mr. Bay. That may happen as soon as this summer but perhaps several months after that. A White House aide and a spokeswoman for Mr. Reid confirmed that deal.

"This is not the outcome Sen. Reid would have preferred, but he accepts the compromise negotiated by Sen. Landrieu and he will move forward with confirming the nominees," said Kristen Orthman, a Reid spokeswoman.
Mr. Reid's continuing involvement in FERC is providing political fodder for Ms. Landrieu's challenger, Rep. Bill Cassidy (R., La.), who criticized Ms. Landrieu's "yes" vote for Mr. Bay.
"We need partners at FERC who put Louisiana families' interests above Harry Reid's," Mr. Cassidy said in a statement Wednesday after the votes.

Sen. Dean Heller of Nevada was the only Republican to join all Democrats in supporting the nomination of Mr. Bay, and independent Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont was the only senator to vote against Ms. LaFleur's nomination.

On Keystone, Republicans voted for it but were critical of Ms. Landrieu's leadership on the issue. Sen. John Barrasso (R., Wyo.). derided the vote as a "show vote" for Ms. Landrieu's re-election race and argued she isn't leading on the issue until or unless she convinces Mr. Reid to allow a floor vote, which is uncertain. The bill passed, 12-10.

The Obama administration has delayed a decision on the Canada-U.S. pipeline until at least after the midterm elections. Environmental opposition has helped delay a final decision for the past few years.

Ms. Landrieu rejected the criticism. "There was no popcorn and Coca-Cola handed out in this meeting; there were no tickets sold to get in," Ms. Landrieu said Wednesday in response to GOP comments: "This is the U.S. Senate Energy Committee. This is about the future of what our energy policy should look like."

Several current and former Senate aides said Keystone isn't in the jurisdiction of the energy committee, saying it would likely go first to the Foreign Relations Committee because it is a cross-border project. Most senators realize the bill is unlikely to become law between now and Election Day, so jurisdictional issues didn't even surface during Wednesday's meeting.
Write to Amy Harder at amy.harder@wsj.com
